<ce:figure id="FIG1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) Extended molecular structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; (b) perspective view of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1a"></ce:link>
<ce:link locator="gr1b"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Extended molecular structure of 1; (b) perspective view of 1 along the b axis.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Extended molecular structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:figure id="FIG3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) Molecular structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> showing the coordination geometry around the central Cd atom; (b) perspective view of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3a"></ce:link>
<ce:link locator="gr3b"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) Molecular structure of 3 showing the coordination geometry around the central Cd atom; (b) perspective view of 3 along the b axis.

Crystal data for the complexes are as follows. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: crystal system, orthorhombic; space group, <ce:italic>Ibam</ce:italic>; <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=11.6084(7), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=12.3793(7), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=15.2789(9) Å; <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: crystal system, orthorhombic; space group, <ce:italic>Pccn</ce:italic>; <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=7.9908(4), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=15.3013(8), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=23.404(1) Å; <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4. <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>: crystal system, monoclinic; space group, <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>; <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=20.505(1), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=11.8106(7), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=23.266(1) Å; <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=104.186(1)°; <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The reaction of Cd(CF3SO3)⋅6H2O with 4,4'-bipyridine in solution yields the 1D complex, {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)4](CF3SO3)2}∞ (1). However, in the presence of 4-methoxy-2-nitroaniline, the same reaction gives a novel 2D intercalation layered complex {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2](CF3SO3)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)2(C7H8N2O3)2}∞ (3) and a 1D intercalation complex {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)(CF3SO3)2(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy)}∞ (2) was obtained under ethanothermal conditions. Crystal data for the complexes are as follows. 1: crystal system, orthorhombic; space group, Ibam; a=11.6084(7), b=12.3793(7), c=15.2789(9) Å; Z=4. 2: crystal system, orthorhombic; space group, Pccn; a=7.9908(4), b=15.3013(8), c=23.404(1) Å; Z=4. 3: crystal system, monoclinic; space group, C2/c; a=20.505(1), b=11.8106(7), c=23.266(1) Å; β=104.186(1)°; Z=4.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Extensive investigations have been recently carried out on the exploration of new square network materials based upon 4-pyridyl-containing or 4-nitrilbenzene derivatives as a building rod mainly due to the theoretical aspects related to the topologies of novel networks and their potential physical and chemical properties, such as electrical conductivity, magnetism, nonlinear optical, zeolite-like properties and applications in host–guest chemistry as well as in catalysis . Furthermore, supramolecular chemistry and self-assembly with 4,4′-bipy and its derivatives are at the frontiers of molecular science, as demonstrated by the intense and the near exponential growth of publications in this area in just the last decade . A CCDC search, showed that there are five crystal structures relative to inclusion phenomenon with 4,4′-bipy: {[Cd(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>
, {[Cd(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>
and [Pd(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(en)](C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) , and {[Cd(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-NAN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> and {[Cd(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](<ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-MENAN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>
. In this paper, we report on the formation and intercalation capability of a one-dimensional infinite chain polymer</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Extensive investigations have been recently carried out on the exploration of new square network materials based upon 4-pyridyl-containing or 4-nitrilbenzene derivatives as a building rod mainly due to the theoretical aspects related to the topologies of novel networks and their potential physical and chemical properties, such as electrical conductivity, magnetism, nonlinear optical, zeolite-like properties and applications in host-guest chemistry as well as in catalysis . Furthermore, supramolecular chemistry and self-assembly with 4,4'-bipy and its derivatives are at the frontiers of molecular science, as demonstrated by the intense and the near exponential growth of publications in this area in just the last decade . A CCDC search, showed that there are five crystal structures relative to inclusion phenomenon with 4,4'-bipy: {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)2](H2O)2⋅PF6 (4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2}∞ , {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2(NO3)2](C6H4Br2)2}∞ and [Pd(4,4'-bipy)2(en)](C10H8)(H2O) , and {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2(ClO4)2](o-NAN)2}∞ and {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)2(ClO4)2](o-MENAN)2}∞ . In this paper, we report on the formation and intercalation capability of a one-dimensional infinite chain polymer

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Chemicals and solvents in this work were purchased from Aldrich and used as received, apart from Cd(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O which was prepared by the reaction of CdCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H in aqueous solution. elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis

Chemicals and solvents in this work were purchased from Aldrich and used as received, apart from Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O which was prepared by the reaction of CdCO3 and CF3SO3H in aqueous solution. The FT-IR spectra were recorded as solids in KBr matrix in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Nicolet 750FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on semi-quantification SEM with EDAX.

After refluxing for 3 h and cooling to room temperature, the solution was filtered by suction. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate at ambient temperature for a few weeks, after which time colorless needle crystals formed in 75% yield based on Cd(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Found: Cd, 17.47; S, 9.85; F, 18.08%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3398(b, s), 1598(m), 1408(m), 1266(s), 1153(m), 1041(m), 805(m), 647.5(m).</ce:para>

{[Cd(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)4](CF3SO3)2}∞ (1)

To a 20 ml ethanol solution containing Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O (0.518 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.312 g, 2.0 mmol), H2O was added dropwise under stirring until the solution became clear or transparent (ca. 2 ml H2O). After refluxing for 3 h and cooling to room temperature, the solution was filtered by suction. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate at ambient temperature for a few weeks, after which time colorless needle crystals formed in 75% yield based on Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O. Anal. Calc. for CdC12H16F6N2O12S2: Cd, 17.60; S, 10.04; F, 17.84. Found: Cd, 17.47; S, 9.85; F, 18.08%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3398(b, s), 1598(m), 1408(m), 1266(s), 1153(m), 1041(m), 805(m), 647.5(m).

After addition of 1 ml 95% EtOH, the tube was frozen with liquid N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, evacuated under vacuum and sealed with a torch. The tube was heated at 90°C for 12 h to give colorless single crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in 65% yield based on Cd(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for CdC<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>F<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: Cd, 14.81; S, 8.45; F, 15.02. Found: Cd, 14.61; S, 8.21; F, 15.24%. IR spectrum (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3418(b, s), 1662(w), 1596(m), 1536(w), 1493(w), 1415(m), 1264(s), 1149(s), 1046(s), 805(s), 648(s).</ce:para>

{[Cd(4,4'-bipy)(CF3SO3)2(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy)}∞ (2)

Samples of 0.259 g (0.5 mmol) Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O, 0.156 g (1.0 mmol) 4,4'-bipy and 0.168 g (1 mmol) 4-methoxy-2-nitroaniline (MNA) were ground, mixed thoroughly in a mortar with pestle, and placed in a thick-walled Pyrex tube (ca. 25 cm long). After addition of 1 ml 95% EtOH, the tube was frozen with liquid N2, evacuated under vacuum and sealed with a torch. The tube was heated at 90°C for 12 h to give colorless single crystals of 2 in 65% yield based on Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O. Anal. Calc. for CdC22H20F6N4O8S2: Cd, 14.81; S, 8.45; F, 15.02. Found: Cd, 14.61; S, 8.21; F, 15.24%. IR spectrum (cm-1): 3418(b, s), 1662(w), 1596(m), 1536(w), 1493(w), 1415(m), 1264(s), 1149(s), 1046(s), 805(s), 648(s).

After refluxing for 3 h and cooling to room temperature, the solution was filtered. Calc. for CdC<ce:inf loc="post">46</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">48</ce:inf>F<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: Cd, 8.73; S, 4.98; F, 8.85. Found: Cd, 8.34; S, 4.71; F, 8.25%. IR spectrum (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3498(m), 3361(s), 1600(m), 1515(m), 1423(m), 1274(s), 1222(sh.m), 1150(m), 1046(m), 804(m), 641(m).</ce:para>

{[Cd(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2](CF3SO3)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)2(C7H8N2O3)2}∞ (3)

In a typical experiment, H2O was added dropwise to a 20 ml EtOH solution containing Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O (0.518 g, 1 mmol), 4,4'-bipy (0.468 g, 3 mmol) and MNA (0.336 g, 2 mmol) under stirring to clear the solution. After refluxing for 3 h and cooling to room temperature, the solution was filtered. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate at ambient temperature for a few weeks, after which time pale yellow block crystals formed in 65% yield based on Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O. Anal. Calc. for CdC46H48F6N10O16S2: Cd, 8.73; S, 4.98; F, 8.85. Found: Cd, 8.34; S, 4.71; F, 8.25%. IR spectrum (cm-1): 3498(m), 3361(s), 1600(m), 1515(m), 1423(m), 1274(s), 1222(sh.m), 1150(m), 1046(m), 804(m), 641(m).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray structure determination for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All the single crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were performed at room temperature using a SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with monochromated Mo K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71069 Å). In each case, a suitable crystal was quickly separated from the mother liquid and coated with epoxy. The unit cell parameters were based on the least-squares refinement of three dimension centroids of 6615 reflections for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 14921 for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and 25360 for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The intensity data were collected using a narrow frame method with scan width of 0.3° in <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic> and exposure times of 10 s/frame. Frames were integrated with the Siemens SAINT program. The SADABS program absorption correction based upon redundant reflections was applied to the data set.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray structure determination for 1-3 

All the single crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were performed at room temperature using a SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71069 Å). In each case, a suitable crystal was quickly separated from the mother liquid and coated with epoxy. The unit cell parameters were based on the least-squares refinement of three dimension centroids of 6615 reflections for 1, 14921 for 2 and 25360 for 3. The intensity data were collected using a narrow frame method with scan width of 0.3° in ω and exposure times of 10 s/frame. Frames were integrated with the Siemens SAINT program. The SADABS program absorption correction based upon redundant reflections was applied to the data set.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The structures were solved by a combination of direct methods and difference Fourier methods, and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques. The calculations were performed using the teXsan crystallographic software package of the Molecular Structure Corporation. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The position of the hydrogen atoms were calculated, but not refined.

The calculations were performed using the teXsan crystallographic software package of the Molecular Structure Corporation. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The position of the hydrogen atoms were calculated, but not refined.   gives crystal data and details for structure analysis for complexes 1-3. elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The results of elemental analysis and IR spectra for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> indicate that the reaction of Cd(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with 4,4′-bipy yielded two different 1D infinite chain polymers, {[Cd(4,4′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Cd(4,4′-bipy)(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](4,4′-bipy)}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). The diagnostic absorption of triflate (1266(s), 1154(m) and 1041(m) cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 1264(s), 1148(s) and 1046(s) cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) is in basic agreement with that of the CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> anion . It is worth noting that under ethanothermal conditions, although there exists a guest in the reactive system, self-assembly only gives a self-co-crystallization one-dimensional polymer complex without guest inducement. This is probably due to the preferential formation of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> depending upon solubility and kinetic stability. A similar situation was also observed in Cd[(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](4,4′-bipy) and Cu[(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](4,4′-bipy) 
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:footnote id="FN1">
<ce:label>1</ce:label>
<ce:note-para>We obtained this compound using a method similar to that for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The unit cell parameters are as follows: <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=16.675(4), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=11.105(3), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=14.374(4) Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>=90.03(2), <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=116.47(1), <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>=89.98(2)°, V=2382.3(2) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>. However, the structure prepared in solution is identical to that prepared under ethanothermal conditions.</ce:note-para>
</ce:footnote>
. However, in solution (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O–EtOH), the self-assembly reaction was significantly influenced by the alien guests and the favorable product is a 2D intercalation complex polymer. The findings suggest that in the final reaction products of CdX<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (X=ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) with 4,4′-bipy, almost all of the favorable final products is a one-dimension coordination polymer if excess 4,4′-bipy not used as the guest. This intercalation ability also exhibits some selectivity. Only 4-methoxy-nitroaniline is effectively intercalated while 3-methoxy-, 5-methoxy- and 6-methoxy-2-nitro isomers are not sandwiched in the layered structure. The recognition of the isomers in the intercalation may be employed for the separation of 4-methoxy-nitroaniline from its isomeric mixture. Similarly, in addition to the characteristic absorption of triflate (1273(s), 1222(sh, m), 1150(m), 1046(m) cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) , the guest NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> stretching vibration mode (3498(m) and 3361(s) cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) was also observed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The results of elemental analysis and IR spectra for 1 and 2 indicate that the reaction of Cd(CF3SO3)2 with 4,4'-bipy yielded two different 1D infinite chain polymers, {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)4](CF3SO3)2}∞ (1) and {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)(CF3SO3)2(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy)}∞ (2). The diagnostic absorption of triflate (1266(s), 1154(m) and 1041(m) cm-1 for 1 and 1264(s), 1148(s) and 1046(s) cm-1 for 2) is in basic agreement with that of the CF3SO3 anion . It is worth noting that under ethanothermal conditions, although there exists a guest in the reactive system, self-assembly only gives a self-co-crystallization one-dimensional polymer complex without guest inducement. This is probably due to the preferential formation of 2 depending upon solubility and kinetic stability. A similar situation was also observed in Cd[(ClO4)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy) and Cu[(ClO4)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy)    1 We obtained this compound using a method similar to that for 2. The unit cell parameters are as follows: a=16.675(4), b=11.105(3), c=14.374(4) Å, α=90.03(2), β=116.47(1), γ=89.98(2)°, V=2382.3(2) Å3. However, the structure prepared in solution is identical to that prepared under ethanothermal conditions.  . However, in solution (H2O-EtOH), the self-assembly reaction was significantly influenced by the alien guests and the favorable product is a 2D intercalation complex polymer. The findings suggest that in the final reaction products of CdX2 (X=ClO4, NO3 and BF4) with 4,4'-bipy, almost all of the favorable final products is a one-dimension coordination polymer if excess 4,4'-bipy not used as the guest. This intercalation ability also exhibits some selectivity. Only 4-methoxy-nitroaniline is effectively intercalated while 3-methoxy-, 5-methoxy- and 6-methoxy-2-nitro isomers are not sandwiched in the layered structure. The recognition of the isomers in the intercalation may be employed for the separation of 4-methoxy-nitroaniline from its isomeric mixture. Similarly, in addition to the characteristic absorption of triflate (1273(s), 1222(sh, m), 1150(m), 1046(m) cm-1) , the guest NH2 stretching vibration mode (3498(m) and 3361(s) cm-1) was also observed.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>), the Cd atom is coordinated to four H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules and two pyridyl groups to form a local octahedral environment while the Cd centers are bridged by 4,4′-bipy ligands, resulting in the formation of a linear Cd–bipy–Cd infinite chain. In addition to static interaction between the cation and anion, O(2) in the anion is hydrogen-bonded to O(1) (coordinated water) (2.766(5) Å). As expected, the bond distances of Cd–O and Cd–N are in the normal range. Quite different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, two oxygen atoms from triflate in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> take part in the coordination to the Cd atom in addition to two water molecules and two nitrogens from the pyridyl group, resulting in a local slightly distorted octahedral geometry. One 4,4′-bipy co-crystallizes with Cd(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bipy) to form a 1D intercalation complex polymer in which the Cd center is also bridged by 4,4′-bipy ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>). The uncoordinated 4,4′-bipy is also hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water (2.772(7) Å). The structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is similar to that of [Cd(4,4′-bipy)(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](4,4′-bipy) , [Cu(4,4′-bipy)(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](4,4′-bipy) , [Mn(4,4′-bipy)(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](4,4′-bipy) and [Co(4,4′-bipy)(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](4,4′-bipy) . There is no significant difference in the average Cd–O and Cd–N bond lengths between compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. It is very interesting to note that in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the Cd atom is bonded to four pyridyl groups and two H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules to form a local six-coordinated complex while the Cd center is bridged by four 4,4′-bipy ligands to produce a square network structure. Each square is capable of sandwiching two MNA molecules, one 4,4′-bipy and two CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> as well as two H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O to form a 2D layered intercalation complex polymer (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>). The distance between the two layers is about 11.81–11.90 Å. The structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is quite different from that of {[Cd(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)}<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) in which only two molecules of C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are clathrated in each square cavity. It should be pointed out that the host structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, [Cd(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, a 2D network, after self-assembly in the presence of a guest (C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>), maintains its two-dimensional structure . However, the host structure of <ce:bold>3, 1</ce:bold>, a 1D infinite chain, in the presence of a guest, rearranges to form a 2D network structure. To our knowledge, the dimension change induced by the guest molecules is a general phenomenon. Moreover the uncoordinated 4,4′-bipy is hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water while there exists a strong intramolecular hydrogen bond (N(5)⋯O(7), 2.643(5) Å) in 4-methoxy-2-nitroaniline. It can be seen from  that the average bond distances of Cd–O and Cd–N are unexceptional. In conclusion, the self-assembly process in the presence of a guest is very flexible and diverse and readily results in a kinetically stable compound while significant changes of the original host structure including the dimension take place. This phenomenon may be general for the Cd(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-4,4′-bipy–guest, Cd(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-4,4′-bipy–guest and Cd(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-4,4′-bipy–guest systems but not for Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-4,4′-bipy–guest.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the crystal structure of 1 ( ), the Cd atom is coordinated to four H2O molecules and two pyridyl groups to form a local octahedral environment while the Cd centers are bridged by 4,4'-bipy ligands, resulting in the formation of a linear Cd-bipy-Cd infinite chain. In addition to static interaction between the cation and anion, O(2) in the anion is hydrogen-bonded to O(1) (coordinated water) (2.766(5) Å). As expected, the bond distances of Cd-O and Cd-N are in the normal range. Quite different from 1, two oxygen atoms from triflate in 2 take part in the coordination to the Cd atom in addition to two water molecules and two nitrogens from the pyridyl group, resulting in a local slightly distorted octahedral geometry. One 4,4'-bipy co-crystallizes with Cd(CF3SO3)2(H2O)2(4,4'-bipy) to form a 1D intercalation complex polymer in which the Cd center is also bridged by 4,4'-bipy ligands ( ). The uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy is also hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water (2.772(7) Å). The structure of 2 is similar to that of [Cd(4,4'-bipy)(ClO4)2(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy) , [Cu(4,4'-bipy)(ClO4)2(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy) , [Mn(4,4'-bipy)(ClO4)2(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy) and [Co(4,4'-bipy)(ClO4)2(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy) . There is no significant difference in the average Cd-O and Cd-N bond lengths between compounds 1 and 2. It is very interesting to note that in 3 the Cd atom is bonded to four pyridyl groups and two H2O molecules to form a local six-coordinated complex while the Cd center is bridged by four 4,4'-bipy ligands to produce a square network structure. Each square is capable of sandwiching two MNA molecules, one 4,4'-bipy and two CF3SO3 as well as two H2O to form a 2D layered intercalation complex polymer ( ). The distance between the two layers is about 11.81-11.90 Å. The structure of 3 is quite different from that of {[Cd(4,4'-bipy)2(NO3)2](C6H4Br2)}∞ (4) in which only two molecules of C6H4Br2 are clathrated in each square cavity. It should be pointed out that the host structure of 4, [Cd(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2](NO3)2, a 2D network, after self-assembly in the presence of a guest (C6H4Br2), maintains its two-dimensional structure . However, the host structure of 3, 1, a 1D infinite chain, in the presence of a guest, rearranges to form a 2D network structure. To our knowledge, the dimension change induced by the guest molecules is a general phenomenon. Moreover the uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy is hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water while there exists a strong intramolecular hydrogen bond (N(5)⋯O(7), 2.643(5) Å) in 4-methoxy-2-nitroaniline. It can be seen from  that the average bond distances of Cd-O and Cd-N are unexceptional. In conclusion, the self-assembly process in the presence of a guest is very flexible and diverse and readily results in a kinetically stable compound while significant changes of the original host structure including the dimension take place. This phenomenon may be general for the Cd(CF3SO3)2-4,4'-bipy-guest, Cd(ClO4)2-4,4'-bipy-guest and Cd(BF4)2-4,4'-bipy-guest systems but not for Cd(NO3)2-4,4'-bipy-guest.

{[Cd(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)4](CF3SO3)2}∞ (1)

To a 20 ml ethanol solution containing Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O (0.518 g, 1.0 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.312 g, 2.0 mmol), H2O was added dropwise under stirring until the solution became clear or transparent (ca. 2 ml H2O). After refluxing for 3 h and cooling to room temperature, the solution was filtered by suction. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate at ambient temperature for a few weeks, after which time colorless needle crystals formed in 75% yield based on Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O. Anal. Calc. for CdC12H16F6N2O12S2: Cd, 17.60; S, 10.04; F, 17.84. Found: Cd, 17.47; S, 9.85; F, 18.08%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1): 3398(b, s), 1598(m), 1408(m), 1266(s), 1153(m), 1041(m), 805(m), 647.5(m).

{[Cd(4,4'-bipy)(CF3SO3)2(H2O)2](4,4'-bipy)}∞ (2)

Samples of 0.259 g (0.5 mmol) Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O, 0.156 g (1.0 mmol) 4,4'-bipy and 0.168 g (1 mmol) 4-methoxy-2-nitroaniline (MNA) were ground, mixed thoroughly in a mortar with pestle, and placed in a thick-walled Pyrex tube (ca. 25 cm long). After addition of 1 ml 95% EtOH, the tube was frozen with liquid N2, evacuated under vacuum and sealed with a torch. The tube was heated at 90°C for 12 h to give colorless single crystals of 2 in 65% yield based on Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O. Anal. Calc. for CdC22H20F6N4O8S2: Cd, 14.81; S, 8.45; F, 15.02. Found: Cd, 14.61; S, 8.21; F, 15.24%. IR spectrum (cm-1): 3418(b, s), 1662(w), 1596(m), 1536(w), 1493(w), 1415(m), 1264(s), 1149(s), 1046(s), 805(s), 648(s).

{[Cd(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2](CF3SO3)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)2(C7H8N2O3)2}∞ (3)

In a typical experiment, H2O was added dropwise to a 20 ml EtOH solution containing Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O (0.518 g, 1 mmol), 4,4'-bipy (0.468 g, 3 mmol) and MNA (0.336 g, 2 mmol) under stirring to clear the solution. After refluxing for 3 h and cooling to room temperature, the solution was filtered. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate at ambient temperature for a few weeks, after which time pale yellow block crystals formed in 65% yield based on Cd(CF3SO3)2⋅6H2O. Anal. Calc. for CdC46H48F6N10O16S2: Cd, 8.73; S, 4.98; F, 8.85. Found: Cd, 8.34; S, 4.71; F, 8.25%. IR spectrum (cm-1): 3498(m), 3361(s), 1600(m), 1515(m), 1423(m), 1274(s), 1222(sh.m), 1150(m), 1046(m), 804(m), 641(m).
